column1: Will the 2020 Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference (NPT RevCon) produce a consensus statement?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']

In light of the situation related to the global coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, States Parties have decided to postpone the 2020 Review Conference of the Parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons to a later date, as soon as the circumstances permit, but no later than April 2021. But maybe the conference cancelled?

This is a rather dramatic revision that may be over-compensating for what now seems like an overly optimistic 40% chance of consensus. However, the pessimism surrounding this review conference seems overwhelming. American proposals have been heavily criticized although these do, somewhat, reflect the lack of progress and the changed international setting. There seems to be no path towards a general consensus and failure to do so is almost assumed.
Coming in from the cold. Good chance the conference doesn't happen by the time this question ends.

Both the US and Russian administration are keen to accelerate research into the next generation of weapons of mass destruction no doubt with the intent of weaponizing space. They will torpedo the conference.

Although thing's look grim, behind the scenes there is still international will (Trump/Iran backed down over Soleimani). Russia is going through a period of change and won't rock the boat ahead of NEW START renewal/extension. Small countries are annoyed about lack of disarmament, but a more transactional Washington alongside the need to work with the Big Powers on issues like Climate Change may strong-arm them.
Breakdown of current order
Different global order, as created by the US has created an environment where no country feels bound by treaties anymore.

With Trump, Russia and NATO, concerns over non-NPT nuclear states, concerns over the future of the INF and New START treaties, and contemporary treaty-making processes more broadly... Looking doubtful. The Economist article is insightful here. That said, there may be diplomatic agreement on particular topic areas, though this would fall outside the scope of the question (a RevCon final document).

With the current state of the world, and the lack of steady diplomatic leadership from the U.S., the odds of consensus on something as consequential as this seem low, despite the need for such consensus.
If there is chatter about including something on hyper velocity vehicles/Space Forces and Satellite weapons in space, this could generate a positive statement.

The petulant nature of the US President will find something to disagree with the other world leaders over and require them to concede to as the price of having the US sign onto a statement. Many will find this unacceptable and not acquiesce to the US bullying leaving without a consensus statement.

There are a number of factors making a consensus statement less likely: American withdrawal from INF; US relations with North Korea and Iran; the rise of China and Russian nuclear modernization are some examples. All tend towards creating pressure on the foundations of the NPT and point to a lack of consensus.

The Nuclear Non-Proliferation world is in disarray. The nuclear haves are not serious about the issue, as shown in the US withdrawal from the Intermediate Range Nuclearn Forces Treaty (1). The nuclear have-nots, such as Turkey, are grumbling about the unfairness of the haves (2). Together with the recent crumpling of the Iranian nuclear agreement, there is no hope for consensus.
Some thing to consider - number of countries participating in the talks, areas of divergence, criticality of divergent issues to participants

The base rate here is 5/9, or about 55%. I'm taking a position that strikes a balance between that base rate and the current consensus, which tends to be a pretty good indicator.

US, Russia and China are fortifying their nuclear arsenal with huge defense outlays. North Korea is playing truant and testing missiles capable of deploying nuclear warheads. There is confrontation brewing between Iran and US in ME. The BJP government in India is unlikely to relent on NPT especially since the previous nuclear tests were carried out under their regime. Considering that the countries who can legitimately hold nuclear weapons are scaling up their nuclear stockpile, it would be absurd to expect the other countries to give up or scale back their nuclear weapons. The chances are bleak that this conference would yield a different outcome than the previous ones.

Will the 2020 Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference (NPT RevCon) produce a consensus statement? Hattip to @Wildwood2000 for sharing sources and setting a low bar for expectations. Things can only get better from this perspective.
Initial estimate

The last NPT RevCon in 2015 was a mess (see: https://cpr.unu.edu/why-the-2015-npt-review-conference-fell-apart.html). Many of the issues that were the cause of the failure to reach consensus in the 2015 RevCon will persist in the 2020 NPT RevCon, with the added complication of Iran's nuclear activity given the demise of the JCPOA and increased regional tensions.
Too little to bind countries together to reach consensus
I hope I'm wrong, but it just doesn't seem at all likely given the way diplomacy has gone lately.

If all nuclear nations are invited, including North Korea, I can see no way for this meeting to produce a concrete resolution. North Korea thinks they are a hotshot. North Korea wants to build an arsenal that makes Kimmy feel safe, which is impossible. There can be no agreement if he is invited.
You can't be sure of anything with current administration
Too many strong personalities willing to mark their presence, incapable of rational discussion
Too wide difference of opinions, too many obstinate leaders willing to mark their presence

Low prioritization on the US Agenda. Lack of energy to compromise here and conflict in trade.

Normally I would begin with the base rate as kindly detailed in the data provided by this forecasting question. However, the U.S. has in general been skeptical of arms control agreements, and is likely to become more so and soon if North Korea follows through on its vague threats against the U.S. Recent activity related to nuclear weapons and an ICBM-capable rocket engine tests may be leading up to something big. https://www.38north.org/, https://www.nknews.org/

Although based on past patterns of consensus i would say that there's at least a 50% chance of producing a consensus statement (seeing as one was reached in 2010 but not in 2015), due to the US pulling out of the Iran deal, the collapse of the INF treaty, North Korea's continued testing, and other factors I find it highly unlikely that a consensus will be reached this year. Non nuclear weapon states will most likely point to the failure to curb Iranian and North Korean nuclear ambitions, in addition to the US and Russia continuing to modernize their own stockpiles, while they are still prohibited for owning nuclear weapons. There will be little room for a consensus if the nuclear armed states cannot credibly convince the non nuclear states that they can ensure the world is moving away from nuclear weapons, which is unlikely given the current international climate and a looming US election.
..A lower forecast seems warranted, but prefer not going down to zero now on something occurring 4-5 months in future.
Down 3% but leaving open the chance some shock to complacency that changes the narrative.

Down 5% to be below the consensus.
The geopolitical priorities of the main protagonists are diverging rather than converging.

Specificity, never a really hot trend in diplomacy, is even less in vogue these days than formerly--so unless the final statement in its entirety is a close paraphrase of "Most of us have probably pretty much agreed not to do too much bad stuff," it won't happen.

"The last few [RevCons] have been flops, with the nuclear haves pitted against the have-nots, rendering it impossible to produce consensus statements in 2005 and 2015. The gathering in 2020 is set to be something of a disaster."

Down 40% now that I've reviewed the bidding. Even if the big 5 were to cooperate to provide a united front (what a quaint idea), other signatories can see reality. The question is whether it is better to hang together or hang separately. In a separate bet, I'd guess it is only time before the DPRK, Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Japan, and S Korea move the hands closer to midnight.
Starting out under 50%, mainly after the 2015 failure to agree plus ongoing, apparent disagreement since, leading up to the 2020 conference.
Initial forecast and placeholder. This would be much more intellectually interesting if the old "process" might have a chance of being part of the mix.
